Award.AwardTitle: Dissecting the Molecular Mechanisms Underlying Intimate Relationship between Cellulose Microfibrils and Cortical Microtubules

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit. Cellulose, an organic compound found in all plants, is the most abundant biological material on earth. Cellulose constitutes the major raw material that is used to produce paperboard, paper, lumber, and textiles. It is also one of the main sources of biomass for the production of renewable biofuels in the near future. Despite overwhelming interest, little is known about how plant cells make cellulose. Cellulose is synthesized by cellulose synthase complexes. Cellulose synthase complexes had long been proposed to interact with cortical microtubules, fibrous structural components within cells, before recent live cell imaging showing that cellulose synthase complexes move on trajectories that parallel the underlying cortical microtubules. Yet a molecular link between microtubules and cellulose synthase complexes is missing. The principle investigator recently identified the first interacting protein of cellulose synthase complexes, named CSI1, which is an excellent candidate for the missing link. The project is aimed to characterize CSI1 with respect to its interactions with cellulose synthase complexes and microtubules. Researchers will use a battery of genetic and biochemical assays and also high-end microscopy to study the connection between cellulose synthase complexes and microtubules, and determine how these connections developed inside the plant cells.

Broader Impacts. The development. of alternatives to fossil fuels as an energy source is an urgent global priority. Lignocellulosic biomass in the form of plant materials (for example, grasses and woody species) offers the opportunity of a renewable, relatively greenhouse-gas-neutral source of sugars that can be converted to ethanol and other liquid fuels. Considering cellulosic biomass are expected to become one of the main sources of biomass for the production of renewable biofuels, understanding the mechanism by which plant cells make cellulose may be of great interest for energy producing agents. The basic knowledge gained from understanding how plants make cellulose will be applied to modify bioenergy crops with regard to traits related to the composition and overall content of biomass. The project will also offer great training opportunities to young scientists including undergraduate, graduate students, and postdocs. This project will allow principal investigator to participate in outreach programs offered by Eberly College of Science at Penn State University, the summer workshop for K-12 teachers and/or students, and High-School Science Project aimed to improve the scientific knowledge of the general group or a specific student group outside of a school setting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The overall goal is to revisit the long-standing questions in the field: How do cortical microtubules influence the deposition of cellulose microfibrils? We utilize Arabidopsis hypocotyl as a model system to address the molecular mechanism by which microtubules guide the deposition of cellulose microfibrils. We demonstrated that the information flow from cortical microtubules to extracellular cellulose microfibrils is dependent on CSI1, a key molecular linker protein named cellulose synthase interactive protein 1 (Figure 1). Arabidopsis genome encodes two CSI1-like genes, namely CSI2 and CSI3. CSI2 is a pseudogene whereas CSI3 shares many similarities with CSI1 including direct interaction with CESAs and co-localization with CSCs. Despite these similarities, CSI3 have a role that is distinct from CSI1. CSI1 has a major role in the guidance of CSCs along microtubules, whereas CSI3 is dispensable for co-alignment of CSCs and microtubules. We have developed toolbox to simultaneously visualize cytoskeleton, CSCs, and their regulators in Arabidopsis and are in a unique position to continue to decipher mechanisms underlying the regulation of cellulose synthesis. 

Publications: We published 15 papers supported by MCB-1121375. These include 8 research papers including 3 papers in Plant Cell, 1 in PNAS, 1 in Plant Physiol, 7 invited reviews including 1 in Curr Opin Plant Biol, 1 in Arabidopsis book, and 1 in Mol Plant. I was a corresponding author on each of peer-reviewed research and review papers except for 1 paper in PLoS ONE and 1 paper in Plant Physiol.

Broader impacts:

Training: A total of 2 female graduate students, 8 undergraduates (4 female), and 5 postdoctoral researchers (4 female) have been supported by this grant for various periods of their training.

Education: In addition to the educational aspects of interdisciplinary scientific training described above, I have the privilege to develop and teach courses at both undergraduate and graduate levels. I have introduced my most current research into the curriculum so that both undergraduate and graduate students can be exposed to the most up-to-date research in the field. I teach General Biochemistry class every fall, which has about 150 undergraduate students. I have introduced the current state of energy crisis, various ways to develop sustainable fuels, highlighting the current development of cellulosic biofuels. My efforts are highlighted in implementing active learning activities into these courses.

Outreach: Outreach to a broader scientific community has taken the form of dissemination of results during visits to Universities and at scientific meetings (25 PI talks, 6 student/postdoc talks, and 20 posters relevant to this research during the course of the grant). My laboratory developed plasmids, fluorescent marker lines, and other genetic tools, and we make them available to scientists around the world at my own expenses of shipping fees. During the course of the grant, I made 35 such mailings. Specific outreach to undergraduates comes from interactions with the undergraduates at PSU (research talks to the undergraduate students) and actively recruiting Underrepresented Minority students (URM) as a member for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Admission Committee. In addition, I have participated in Women in the Sciences and Engineering (WISE) at PSU. I also served as a Science Fair judge for middle school students at Young Scholars of Central Pennsylvania thus reaching a younger audience.
